Navigation
Name Rascal/Statements/Assignment/IsDefined
Synopsis Assign but replace if value is not defined.
Syntax Assignable ? Exp2 = Exp1
Description First the value of Exp1 is determined and if that is defined it is assigned to Assignable. Otherwise, the value of Exp2 is assigned to Assignable.
Examples First assign to N: 
rascal>N = 1;
int: 1
and use ?= to assign to N (nothing spectacular here): 
rascal>N ?= 5;
int: 1
rascal>N;
int: 1
Now explore what happens if we do this to an undefined variable X: 
rascal>X;
|stdin:///|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>): Undeclared variable: X
rascal>X ?= 3;
int: 3
rascal>X;
int: 3
rascal>Y ? 0 += 3;
|stdin:///|(0,1,<1,0>,<1,1>): Uninitialized variable: Y
Is this ok? This is a common idiom to handle undefined key in maps: Introduce a may M that does not contain a key "cef". 
rascal>M = ("abc": 1, "def" : 2);
map[str, int]: ("abc":1,"def":2)
Using an isDefined assignable can we increment a non-existing entry: 
rascal>M["cef"] ? 0 += 1;
map[str, int]: ("abc":1,"cef":1,"def":2)
rascal>M["cef"];
int: 1
